meanings.definition: (Latin) to incite, stir up, urge on
meanings.english_definition: (Latin) to set in motion, to urge forward, to excite, to spur on

examples.sentence: Musa, mihi causas memora, quo numine laeso, quidve dolens, regina deum tot volvere casus insignem pietate virum, tot adire labores impulerit. Tantaene animis caelestibus irae?
examples.translation: Muse, tell me the reasons, with what divine will offended, or grieving at what, the queen of the gods drove a man, outstanding in piety, to undergo so many misfortunes, to face so many toils. Can there be such great anger in heavenly minds?
examples.note: Although 'impulerit' is used in this example, 'incitari' would have a similar meaning of 'to drive' or 'to urge on'.

etymology.value: From in- (in, on) + citare (to put in motion, summon, rouse).

usage_notes.note: Often used to describe the act of provoking someone or something into action, sometimes with negative connotations (e.g., inciting a riot).
